utterances: A challenge that's expected to add up to a massive 600 to $700 million deficit next year.
Msall says Emanuel is on the right track.
He used an executive order to create a long-range financial planning process, and the budget is one of his top priorities.
For the past couple of weeks, the mayor has held press conferences - showcases of sorts - to detail how the city is working to shave costs.
Good morning and welcome to the Jardine Water Filtration Plant...
At this meeting at one of Chicago's water filtration plants, department heads talked about how they're changing business-as-usual procedures.
Water department officials said instead of tearing up streets to repair sewers, they'll install more liners that extend the life of the city's sewers.
Two other departments plan to merge.
And the city will reduce the size of its vehicle fleet and install Zipcar technology so workers share cars.
Emanuel says the group came up with initiatives to save $14 million.

I asked everybody, like we're doing, is to go through the budgets, not get stuck to old ways, but ask some fundamental questions, going line by line, which is, is this the best way to deliver this service?
Labor leaders say the efficiency report they've offered Mayor Emanuel could save Chicago as much as $242 million.
It's a familiar theme: Dueling ideas about what to cut and how.
Cheryl Corley, NPR News, Chicago.
(Soundbite of theme song ""Here Come the Yankees"")
Unidentified Singers: Here come the Yankees.
Let's get behind and cheer the Yankees...
Last night, The House That Ruth Built roared to life for the last time.
The Yankees are moving to a new home, leaving behind generations of memories.
(Soundbite of vintage Yankees game broadcast)
Unidentified Announcer: A tremendous smash bar over the left field fence for a home run by Joe DiMaggio.
From home runs to heavyweight knockouts, for more than 80 years the ballpark was the stage for countless sporting masterpieces, as well as musical maestros and mass with the Pope.
Along the way, the stadium managed to weave its way into popular culture.
(Soundbite of song ""Joltin' Joe DiMaggio"")
Unidentified Singer: He started baseball's famous streak, That's got us all aglow.
He's just a man and not a freak, Joltin' Joe DiMaggio.
The building's grandeur may not be due to the singular moments that occurred there, but to the characters on the field who called it home, men like Mickey Mantle, Joe DiMaggio, and Lou Gehrig.
(Soundbite of Lou Gehrig's farewell to baseball address)
Today, I consider myself the luckiest man on the face of the earth.
Last night, Arun Venugopal from member station WNYC reminisced with fans lucky enough to be at the final game.
With just a couple of hours to go before the last game to be played ever at Yankee Stadium, the streets outside were bustling with fans.
Most had tickets for the big game, but some stood forlorn, silently holding up a single finger for that one ticket that they hoped to acquire.
Mr.
BERNIE BERMUDEZ(ph) (Yankees Fan): They had a good ballpark.
There will never be nothing like this in this world, in the whole world, nothing.
Bernie Bermudez had $1,000 to spend on the ticket.
And if he did get in, he was hoping to sneak out with a little bit of the stadium.
Maybe you'll be able to get something if you're lucky, if you're lucky.
I don't know.
I'll try to get down to the field somehow and try to get some dirt or something like that.
You know, anything that is memories of them, even if it's a piece of grass, a piece of wood, a piece of bench, anything.
You know what I mean?
Memories are good memories, I say.
You know what I mean?
There are plenty of opinions about what made Yankee Stadium work.
Terry Trainer(ph) was selling baseball cards outside the stadium and had his own theory.
It's the vessel that holds all these memories within, and it symbolizes our connection to the land.
The baseball field itself - because baseball comes from our agrarian past - it does serve to tie us to our land.
Trainer and other fans suspect Yankee management was less interested in the game's history and more interested in commerce.
Yankee owner George Steinbrenner and his sons are building their new $1.3 billion stadium across the street.
Alyssa Wiles(ph) has been coming to the stadium since the days of Mickey Mantle.
People come from all over the world to see this stadium, and it's really a shame that we don't want to preserve that heritage.
I'm sure the new one will be beautiful, but it won't be the old one.
There are also fans who are excited about the new stadium.
Joe Meely(ph) is a big, sturdy guy who's watched stars like Yogi Berra and Reggie Jackson.
But he said the old stadium is crowded and not too comfortable.
Still...
I get welled up every time I go to the stadium with the wall of champions there.
It just brings back a lot of memories, you know, of the guys that are long gone.
But you remember when they played.
And you know, it's just a bright spot in your life, I think.
The Yankees left their fans with some more memories last night, defeating the Orioles 7-3.
The team plays their next regular season home game against Cleveland.
That game's schedule for April 16, 2009, in the lavish new place across the street, also called Yankee Stadium.
For NPR News, I'm Arun Venugopal.
